review_title: Africare needs new leadership to survive.
pros: Africare employees are passionate about the work, and they are committed to the organization's mission.
cons: There are many issues at Africare. 1) The organization has no direction. Africare adopted an "anything goes" approach to business. There's no BD strategy except "get any money you can find." 2) Africare, much like its senior leadership team, is having an identity crisis. Africare will change its competencies to suit the checkbook of its donors, even if they have no real experience in that sector. 3) The organization is fighting to stay relevant in an innovative landscape, but somehow refuses to invest in innovative concepts, employees or partners. 4) Africare boasts that "95 percent" of its staff is African, but there are no Africans in leadership positions at headquarters. 6) The senior leadership team is like the unpopular group of kids from HS who are now adults and are very determined to shed those personas. They are reckless leaders, completely oblivious to how low morale is, and worst of all, they are willing to demoralize their employees to make a point. As a result, the employee attrition rate has skyrocketed. 7) Hard work will not advance you at Africare. If senior leadership likes you enough, they'll make a new position for you. If not, be ready for your termination of employment.

pros: Good people to work with
cons: A former colleague of mine sent me a text about the reviews of Africare on this website.  I checked it out and decided to weigh in.  Working at Africare is like reliving your high school years. You have good friends, the "in-crowd", and the crowd on the outside looking in, the mean girl clique, good bosses and bad bosses.  The building that houses Africare is an old school, which is very appropriate. My time at Africare was not that bad because I made sure to get in with the “in-crowd” the top dogs of the place.  Its all a game and you have to play to stay. What I found to be very interesting is the number of people that asked me what is going on at Africare during interviews with other organizations.  I guess the number of Africare staff looking for jobs has raised some eyebrows.  My advice to those looking for work at Africare is get in with the in crowd, you will know who they are as soon as you walk in the door.  They are the only ones smiling.

review_title: Fearful culture, low morale, high rate of employee dissatisfaction
pros: None that I can think of at the moment.
cons: When I started at Africare a few years ago we had a full management staff and over 50 employees in the home office.  During the last year we have lost at least 24 employees in the home office and 92% of management staff.  Africare is a mere shadow of its former self and that shadow is fading quickly. The building is almost empty, its like working in a country after a war.  All of the life and vibrancy is gone, replaced with long, sad faces, fear, confusion, unbelief and anger.  The question of the day is always, "What happened to Africare?"  With no management staff we barely function, existing only memories of the old days, the building whispers of the good old days when you would hear people hard at work, laughing, joyous at working to create a better Africa.  We do very little program work because there is no experienced leadership. Funding is dwindling to a trickle. At least 90% of the staff is looking for jobs we even share job openings with each other.  The days are now spent waiting for the email "Africare finally closes its doors."

review_title: Great place to be part of development change
pros: Small NGO doing big things in Africa.  Friendly staff, comfortable working space. Opportunity to learn a lot about all aspects of international development. Great place for beginners.
cons:
Few chances to advance to overseas offices. Organization builds up employee portfolio only to watch them leave. Transformed from a really productive staff full of historical knowledge to newbies from outside that are have credentials but low on real experience and high on power tripping..  CEO has left so maybe there will be a turnaround.  competitive wages only for upper management staff.
Needs to expand and welcome new and innovative ideas more.

review_title: Good place to get experience, but don't look for recognition or formal career advancement opportunities.
pros: You get a lot of experience and it's easy to pursue areas that interest you. You are not stuck in a "box" if you don't want to. In addition, field staff are dedicated and amazing to work with. Health insurance for HQ employees is 100% paid.
cons: Management does not recognize or appreciate staff. There are not many opportunities for advancement in the organization. Systems are generally weak. There are sometimes dubious recruitment practices and you sometimes wonder how some staff members got their jobs with such limited capacity.

job_title: Project Officer in Abuja, Federal Capital Territory
pros:
Great Place to learn how to "sink or swim" 

If you can survive the working environment you can survive any working environment
cons:
Pay isn't that great compared to other non-profit organisations. 

Policies aren't spelled out clearly. Also roles and responsibilities among staff aren't clear so you end up doing everybody's job except yours.

review_title: Sadly, Africare  is not living up to legacy of its founders
pros: Well intentioned leadership has not managed to turn Africare around. Staff morale remains at an all time low. Signs that organization  is in trouble abound. Board seems asleep at the wheel.
cons:
Mass staff exodus -- 4 Chief Financial Officers in 3 years; Award winning agriculture department  has lost entire staff and  is in total disarray; New head of Health Dept quit after only 3 months,  Monitoring and Evaluation Dept no longer exists;Lead expert on gender has been pushed out; Precipitous drop in new business awards. 

Climate of fear ---don't dare speak up...you will be fired.

pros: Very few positive things to say. They did have a nice 401k policy and insurance...
cons:
Turn over: There has been a mass exodus over the past two years. Some have been fired (for due reason) and most have quit. Of these people who have left, most haven't been replaced. For instance, one of their technical units went from a staff of 4 down to one and for a while they had zero staff in another department (forcing others who are untrained/unqualified to do that work). 

In crowd: There is an in crowd and then everyone else. The in crowd gets promotions and raises while under performing and taking credit for everything they didn't do. Now this can happen from time to time at any organization, however at Africare this is the status quo. 

Leadership: The leadership... what to say about them. Their priorities are out of whack.  Their highest priority seems to be raising indirect funding to cover overhead as opposed to increasing their technical capabilities to win new projects and turn their organization around. The existing projects are suffering because they are not being supported and no one is doing anything except trying to raise private funds.

The projects: The country staff are amazing, they are so dedicated to the mission, and may be the only ones. The projects are under supported by HQ, technically and managerial.  Several of the projects have almost been shut down by the donor, due to mismanagement. Not a great sign of new incoming business.

Moral: Moral is at an all time low. Projects are ending and Africare isn't winning new project. People are worried about their jobs, not to mention they are overworked because they haven't hired anyone new. Its a hard time for Africare and there is no sign that things are going to turn around.

I wouldn't recommend working here, unless you really enjoyed middle school drama.

pros:
You are encouraged to attend lots of conferences and engagement opportunities 
Management has an open door policy
Small tight knit group that works together as a team
Promote from within
cons:
Senior management is cliquish 
Small organization (DC location) so staff gossip about each other
High turnover
Constant worry about financial status of the company and risk of downsizing

pros: I was able to learn a lot and work with a hardworking and dynamic team. I felt that the work we did made a difference in the communities.
cons: The administrative bottlenecks some times slowed down the field work.

pros: Travel for those hired under traveling to different countries in  Africare.
cons: Be very mindful of whats happening at HQ. Things happen there in a fish bowl. No matter what position, your job can be gone, just like that!

review_title: Improving work culture, good staff with strong intent to serve mission
pros: strong beginning efforts to improve staff moral, work satisfaction and decrease excessive turn over
cons: low staff moral due to bad priorities; lack of empowerment of non-management staff

Exposure to multiple facets of the International Development industry
Work-life balance
cons:
Lack of a clear leadership vision
Silo-ed departments
Stretched financial and human resources

cons: everything, from the staff in survival mode (backstabbing, finger pointing....) to the hiring processes (friends, relatives...). CEO borrows endowments money to keep doors opened
